review_title: Work hard but you don't know for what
pros:
Good working conditions
If you have the luck to be on a good organisation and to have a good manager then it could be a good place to work.
You can learn many things.
If you negotiate well you can have a decent compensation(depending on the level).
You can meet some very smart people in Amazon.
cons:
As someoane else pointed out, it is darwinian, survival of the strong work place.

There are some organisations, like RBS that are full of bad managers.

The principle of Deal with uncertainty is taken to the extreme. You will never know what to expect in the near future. Often there is a change only because the managers need to check their acomplishments. I have seen sittuations where a tool was build, used for a few mnths then deprecated. Other times a tool used for years that worked well was replaced with a new one worse in every aspect.

In my case the evaluation was made based on objectives that were not even communicated to me by the manager(because he was so "busy" that I could rarely talk to him).

If you don't do politics or are not willing to be like the managers want you to be, you are forced to leave.

review_title: Worst place to be managing people
pros: They pay comprehensive salary and good benefits.
cons:
I am one of the manager in CTPS(TRMS). Before joining Amazon, I worked in different companies and worked under lot of leaderships but I haven't seen such a selfish leadership in my career. They can go to any extent to reach their personal goals, because the performance system is built in such manner. They have a Metrix called URA - unregretted attrition and this pushes them to take hard decisions otherwise they will not reach their goals. There are certain managers in AMAZON who fights for their team however the dept I was in was bit different. They were happy to see people move or resign so that they can reach their targets, sometimes they remove people by false reports. Being an employee, I have seen them doing and due to this many managers left the company or moved to different departments. In just two years, 7-8 managers left one of the division because of bad leadership management. I am perplexed that the company hasn't noticed and they still persist with the same leadership on top.

Note: They have removed people even during this pandemic.

review_title: Really cool exposure, with job commoditization breathing down your neck
job_title: Cloud Support Engineer I in Cape Town
pros:
You'll get to put together some really cool stuff (probably) for some high-profile enterprises (hopefully). This sometimes allows you to make a name for yourself, and connect with some super bright minds.

The informal AWS 'alumni network', provided you're playing ball yourself, is excellent. I'm in good touch with many of my ex-colleagues, and continue to work with some as well, albeit at different companies.

You're never unaware of what your role is - even if it's "churn out tickets, ticket monkey". If I've achieved that, I can end my workday and rest easy.

If you play the AWS game well, you can wangle promotions in a relatively straightforward way and move your way out into other orgs. Likewise you can coast along and be fairly comfortable in a familiar role.
cons:
The sheer scale can be quite overwhelming. You'll never be the smartest person in a given room (which is a good thing too!) but it's tricky to stand out among some talented folks.

While there's emphasis on being able to escalate issues beyond line management, in practice that doesn't happen. Couple this with a roll of the dice for management ability and you're in for a wild ride.

Project/creative work exists, but is effectively actively discouraged by heavy ticket quota requirements. It's the Amazon standard - job commoditization. Want to do something that actually might improve things for colleagues and customers? That's fine, but do it on your own time. Amazon time is for tickets - 45/month, and you'll know in fairly short time if you're not 'keeping up'.

Basically, don't expect to be able to exercise much humanity here. You can get along just fine and make some decent money, meet some good people and progress really nicely, but if you have any creative itches or feel a need to see the works your hands hath made, you're straight outta luck. Your job is to resolve tickets, and there are hundreds of thousands of them. Many many people in the same role will be achieving ~10x your numbers, which invariably skews quotas and feeds bad data to data-obsessed upper management, which in turn increases required quota across the board - the cycle continues.

review_title: Great place to be challenged and learn.  Stifling politics and bureaucracy.
pros:
- Working with some very talented people
- Ability to take ownership for your work
- Majority of projects will benefit the end customer
- Travel to other countries / sites
cons:
- Majority of employees focused on themselves and their promotion, not on the end customer, so the game playing was stifling
- Little / no on boarding with line management refusing to help purely because no one helped them when they joined (this is not a place for the faint hearted).
- No formal manager training so it depended on whether you got lucky or not with whom you got to manage you, on their management skills.
- It is a doc heavy culture with most approvals requiring a doc to be written and approved. Nit-picking on docs by some co-workers because they had nothing constructive to say, made for a very challenging and long approval process.
- Promotion system is dependent on how well you get on with your manager / skip levels, not through meritocracy.

review_title: Very poor experience, just a number to a corporation
pros: Pay is decent for a starting position without the need for a degree. PTO accumulates at a passable rate and it's done through an app so you don't need to make excuses for asking for time off.
cons:
Decent pay requires you to work awful hours overnight, the physical labor is constant and unyielding, positions above the entry-level do absolutely no work compared to new hires and get paid more. Social distancing guidelines (stay 6 feet apart) are set in place where it is physically impossible to follow them because of how close we have to be to work efficiently, meanwhile, you get scolded for breaking them. The Bellingham Amazon warehouse had the highest rate of Covid with employees in New England because of this. 
Constantly on a timer and being tracked with cameras everywhere, all you are is a number to Amazon because they can afford the constant influx of new employees. The vast majority of new employees left within a month, many even within a week.

job_title: Currently Unemployed And Seeking Work in Kissimmee, FL
pros: The pay and benefits are very good and being able to say that you work for Amazon is an added bonus.
cons: The metrics they expect you to maintain just don't correlate with the customer service they expect you to provide. Its frowned upon to spend too much time on a phone call even though sometimes excellent customer service requires it. A lot of the times the resources that you rely on on a daily basis are not functioning properly or at all, sometimes they are outdated and not reliable. They say that they want you to be innovative and bring ideas to the table but when you do then they give you the other cheek. For such a big company, I'd expect better processes and resources for employees. Oh and god forbid you need to escalate a call!

pros: I made some great friends there surprisingly and was paid relatively well.
cons:
Job wasn’t  as described and the interview process doesn't invite you to understand if the job is a good fit for you, they want you find if you're a good fit for them. They also don't give out salary details but expect you to put an extensive amount of work in to the interview. 
They aim to hire people working 50% over the people already working in the same position so you are likely to be unfulfilled in the position and not given any challenging work. 

The team I was on was not diverse at all. It was very clear to me that I was an ethnic minority in a sea of white people. There were a lot of women in the team however as a whole, there was significantly more male employees then women in the building and within 3 months I had been propositioned 3 times. 

It was an absolutely terrible place to work and I am very glad to be rid of the place. I worked with many departments across Amazon and I would say that not all departments seem to be unhappy but this particular one was consistently loosing staff.

review_title: Good work life and very considerate about the employee
pros: Managers are really considerate and the work is really interesting with lors to learn.
cons: Working hours are really high during the peak times

pros: Flexible schedule - you can start from 7, 8 or 9 a.m.
cons:
Salary - it is kind of low considering the amount of work, stress, sometimes overtime and huge amount of updates/process changes on a weekly basis. Another thing is that Amazon does not offer any kind of bonus: I had even 400% productivity and I received the exactly same salary which is quite unfair

Useless for future jobs - you learn processes specific only for Amazon which cannot be applied to any other companies. You learn policies and processes which help Amazon work, but they are not applied outside of it. So if you want to build a career and gain experience and skills, this is not a suitable position.
For me personally, the tasks were repetitive and became boring over time. Plus the management is not open to moving you to another department or team

Stress and overtime - the pressure when the deadlines must be met which can lead to stress and overtime sometimes. We had situations when the management dis not provide the samples on time and we had to work a lot in a short period of time. 
Regarding overtime, it is not paid in Amazon, only if you work during the weekend. If it is during the week, we do not get paid for extra hours.

Promotions - I saw that you have to give it all to get there. They even hire Quality Analyst Specialists (L4 level) externally, even if there are hardworking Quality Analysts (L3) already in Amazon. I consider this to be unfair and current employees can lose motivation this way.

Funny fact: in Amazon it was my first time I heard that we can organize a teambuilding with our money because the budget was not approved (considering the CEO is the richest human in the world)

review_title: They care about technonology & numbers, NOT people
job_title: Inventory Control Specialist in Oakland, CA
pros: entry level jobs, flexible schedules
cons: Amazon cares about numbers and technology. There is constant pressure for UPH (units per hour) That is their primary focus. If you do not make their numbers then you are micro-managed. If you are part time sometimes your hours can be cut to a minimum. This is not the job for you if you care about people and want to work in a sociable environment as Amazon discourages human interactions. Amazon prefers to hire externally for their management jobs. If you have been with Amazon for a while you come to feel that it was meant to be a short term job. Amazon does not protect long time employees and they seem to prefer a workforce with continuous turnover.

pros:
Salary is decent for a product company
Excellent Opportunities to Learn and express yourself
cons:
* No Work-Life Balance
* No Compensatory off for working over weekend
* Over time allowance etc are only on Papers
* One cannot plan for a long vacation easily and it is against the policy to club your leave with Long weekend
* Only 5 mandatory holidays and everything else is put under Optional Holiday, you need to plan your leave in advance for any festival which otherwise is a mandatory holiday 
* Paid Leaves are distributed into 2 categories where you can avail all leave in one category at once and you cannot take more than 2 days leave in continuation in the other category. Basically you can plan only one vacation which is longer than 7 days per calendar year
* Customer Obsession is misused totally and employees are expected to follow customer madness. People here go to any extent to please the customer and employees who are actually executing the task is treated no less than a slave to meet these goals
* Company is run by managers from Service company from top to bottom so don't expect it any better than a worst service company you know
* RSUs are only Eye Candy. Majority of the employees wont sustain beyond 2-3 years and even if they sustain, company will lay them off to save RSU payouts. Only if you are an exceptional candidate and boot licker then you will survive to enjoy your RSU payout

review_title: Not at all like the commercials
pros:
Vaca, personal time, genuinely good medical- decent dental, okay vision coverage. Entry level management teir 6 upto 8 0 k /year.
>Expect30k/yr if your entry level.
cons: Force you to work mandatory extra time when they say to. Basically do not give any major US holidays off to employees, (entry level gets half a day off, management stay entire day). Give you vacation and personal time in small slivers weekly [avergae employee will recieve 2.2 hrs to and 47 minutes vaca per week until max out respectively] versus giving vacation/PTO upfront/all at once. As management our hands our tied, we cannot do anything. This isn't a true management position- even at teir 6. ALSO, I can write you up and never need to have the stones to tell you that I did, nor why I did it. I can write you up for something that you can properly justify and never give you a chance to defend yourself. There is seldom enough equipment to go around to the team members, upper management breathes down my throat all the time, but in writing they seem so nice. Amazon contradicts itself constantly. Hires people then vto s them. 14 hour days (called 11's) 30 mins for lunch, plus show up 45 min early/stay 45min late, and the commute to and from = 14 hour days year round. Plus, do that 5 days per week during peak. And don't forget to check in on your pa's on your days off, or else.
